fragment.text: [visit_brand] has determined that we can safely provide online care to patients between the ages of 8 and 65 years for tick bites. Because you do not meet the age guidelines for tick bites, we cannot safely provide online care for you today. You will not be charged for this [visit_noun]. Thanks for using [visit_brand].
You told us that you were not bitten by a tick. For this reason, you do not need medication to prevent Lyme Disease. You will not be charged for this [visit_noun]. Thanks for using [visit_brand].

You have told us that you have an elevated temperature. This could indicate a more serious health problem. For this reason, we cannot safely provide online care for you today. Please be seen in a clinic or urgent care for further evaluation today. You will not be charged for this [visit_noun].

You told us that the affected area of your skin is red and swollen. For this reason, I cannot safely provide online care for you today. Please be seen today in a clinic or urgent care to determine the best treatment for you. You will not be charged for this [visit_noun]. Thanks for using [visit_brand]

Because you were unable to upload a photo of your skin, I am unable to safely treat you online. Please be seen in a clinic or urgent care to receive a diagnosis and treatment plan. You will not be charged for this [visit_noun]. Thanks for using [visit_brand].
The patient is a minor and has consent from a parent/guardian to receive medical care.
A synchronous visit is necessary because the patient reported the following abnormal symptoms:
• Affected area of skin is red and swollen
• Unable or prefers not to upload photo
uploaded images of the affected area of
like an image of a blacklegged deer tick.
City and state where the tick bite occurred as reported by the patient (free text):
The affected area of the skin
Based on the information you provided, you likely have a Deer tick bite with development of a bull's-eye rash.
Based on the information you provided, you likely have a tick bite from an undetermined species.

Based on the information you have provided, I am unable to diagnose and treat you without additional information. A more complete health history, examination, and testing are possibly needed. Because we care about your health, please be seen in a clinic or urgent care to determine the best treatment for you. You will not be charged for this [visit_noun]. Thanks for using [visit_brand].

Based on the information you provided during your interview, a conversation with a [customer_name] [provider_noun] was required in order to diagnose and treat you. I attempted to contact you several times but have not been able to reach you. For this reason, I cannot safely provide you with treatment recommendations at this time. Because we care about your health, please be seen in a clinic or urgent care to determine the care that is best for you. You will not be charged for this [visit_noun]. Thanks for using [visit_brand].

Based on the information you provided during our conversation, I am unable to diagnose and treat you today. Please call our [customer_name] priority line for a scheduler to assist you with arranging an appointment. You will not be charged for this [visit_noun]. Thanks for using [visit_brand].
Calamine as needed. This is an over-the-counter medication that does not require a prescription.
Doxycycline. Take one tablet by mouth two times a day for 14 days.

<DrugDescription>doxycycline Hyclate (Vibramycin) 100mg oral tablet</DrugDescription><Strength>100</Strength><StrengthQualifier>mg</StrengthQualifier><Quantity>28</Quantity><QuantityQualifier>tablets</QuantityQualifier><RefillCount>0</RefillCount><Sig>Take one tablet by mouth two times a day for 14 days</Sig><DaysSupply>14</DaysSupply><DrugForm>oral tablet</DrugForm><RefillAsNeeded>FALSE</RefillAsNeeded><AllowSubstitution>TRUE</AllowSubstitution><NDC>69095050</NDC>
Amoxicillin. Take one tablet by mouth three times a day for 14 days.

<DrugDescription>amoxicillin 500mg oral tablet</DrugDescription><Strength>500</Strength><StrengthQualifier>mg</StrengthQualifier><Quantity>42</Quantity><QuantityQualifier>tablets</QuantityQualifier><RefillCount>0</RefillCount><Sig>Take one tablet by mouth three times a day for 14 days</Sig><DaysSupply>14</DaysSupply><DrugForm>oral tablet</DrugForm><RefillAsNeeded>FALSE</RefillAsNeeded><AllowSubstitution>TRUE</AllowSubstitution><NDC>66336029330</NDC>
Cefuroxime. Take one tablet by mouth two times a day for 14 days.

<DrugDescription>cefuroxime axetil (Ceftin) 500mg oral tablet</DrugDescription><Strength>500</Strength><StrengthQualifier>mg</StrengthQualifier><Quantity>28</Quantity><QuantityQualifier>tablets</QuantityQualifier><RefillCount>0</RefillCount><Sig>Take one tablet by mouth two times a day for 14 days</Sig><DaysSupply>14</DaysSupply><DrugForm>oral tablet</DrugForm><RefillAsNeeded>FALSE</RefillAsNeeded><AllowSubstitution>TRUE</AllowSubstitution><NDC>0173-0394-00</NDC>

If you find a tick attached to your skin, there are several tick removal devices on the market, but a plain set of fine-tipped tweezers will remove a tick quite effectively. Use the tweezers to:

  • Grasp the tick as close to the skin's surface as possible.
  • Pull upward with steady, even pressure. Don't twist or jerk the tick; this can cause the mouth-parts to break off and remain in the skin. If this happens, remove the mouth-parts with tweezers. If you are unable to remove the mouth easily with clean tweezers, leave it alone and let the skin heal.
  • After removing the tick, thoroughly clean the bite area and your hands with rubbing alcohol, an iodine scrub, or soap and water.
  • Avoid folklore remedies such as 'painting' the tick with nail polish or petroleum jelly, or using heat to make the tick detach from the skin. Your goal is to remove the tick as quickly as possible--not waiting for it to detach.

If you develop a rash or fever within several weeks of removing a tick, go to a clinic for evaluation. Be sure to tell the clinician about your recent tick bite: when the bite occurred, and where you were when you were bitten.

question.label: Where were you at the time you were bitten by a tick? Please enter the city and state below.
Do you have any of these symptoms?
A rash that resembles a target
A photo of the affected area of your skin is required in order to diagnose and treat you. Are you able to take and upload a photo of your condition?
Please upload 2 to 3 photos for your clinician to review.
Are you able to take your temperature now?
Are you allergic to any of these antibiotics?
Please list the names of any other medications to which you are allergic. If you do not have any medication allergies, please type 'none'.

The Infectious Disease Society of America (IDSA) does not generally recommend antimicrobial prophylaxis for prevention of Lyme disease after a recognized tick bite. However, in areas that are highly endemic for Lyme disease, a single dose of doxycycline may be offered to adult patients (200 mg) who are not pregnant and to children older than 8 years of age (4 mg/kg up to a maximum dose of 200 mg) when all of the following circumstances exist:
Instructions for safely removing a tick from skin
